answers: dictionaries [accept The Devil’s Dictionary; accept Dictionary of the Khazars or Hazarski rečnik]
lawyers [or attorneys; accept anything relating to practicing law]
parts: Name these works, a satirical "Devil's" one of which was written by Ambrose Bierce. The “Petit Larousse” is a famous French one of these works.

Henry Black wrote the first two editions of an authoritative dictionary used by people with this profession. In order to become part of this profession, prospective members must pass the "bar exam", for which each state has a different version.

This board game also maintains its own dictionary, which lists all the words which may be played in it. Players in this board game take turns playing tiles on a 15-by-15 board to form words, scoring more points for using rarer letters like the Q and Z.

answers: temperance movement [or prohibitionist movement; accept teetotalism; accept any descriptive answers like banning alcoholic drinks]
parts: Identify this social cause which sought to ban the consumption of beverages like beer, rum, and bourbon in the United States.
Carrie Nation, a radical temperance activist, was infamous for violently attacking saloons and bars using one of these weapons to destroy kegs of alcohol.

During the prohibition era, this Chicago gangster built an empire on the sale of illegal alcohol, a practice known as bootlegging. Nicknamed "Scarface", this perpetrator of the St. Valentine's Day Massacre would later be jailed at Alcatraz after his conviction for tax evasion.

answers: Albus Percival Brian Wulfric Dumbledore [accept either underlined portion]
parts: This headmaster of Hogwarts in the Harry Potter series had an affair with Gellert Grindelwald. He was murdered by Severus Snape in the sixth Harry Potter novel.
In the Percy Jackson series, Nico di Angelo, a son of this Greek god, is forced by Cupid to come out as gay. This member of the Big Three put Nico and his sister Bianca in the Lotus Hotel.

This author wrote Two Boys Kissing and Boy Meets Boy, two books featuring gay characters. This author also cowrote Will Grayson, Will Grayson with John Green, a book that centers around the fact that a straight boy and a gay boy both share the title name.

answers: the Golden Horde [or Altan Ord, or Altın Urda, or Ulug Ulus, or the Ulus of Jochi, or the Kipchak Khanate; prompt on the Great Horde]
parts: Name this largest contiguous land empire in world history. It stretched from Siberia to Eastern Europe, eventually fracturing into several smaller realms such as the Chagatai Khanate.
This grandson of Genghis established the Yuan Dynasty in China, becoming the first non-Han emperor to control all of China after his conquest of the Song Dynasty and accession to the imperial throne.

This successor state of the Mongol Empire was founded by Batu Khan and ruled over the steppes of Eastern Europe and Central Asia. It was eventually defeated by Muscovy at the Great Stand on the Ugra River.
Name this French composer who is best known for pieces like La mer and Clair de lune.

Debussy was influenced by Inayat Khan, a Sufi mystic and musician from this country. Ravi Shankar is a musician who plays the sitar, a traditional instrument from this country, and its classical music is based on the principles of raga and tala.

Debussy was known for his musical integration of silence, something that was taken perhaps a bit too far by this American minimalist composer in his work 4'33", in which the performer sits still for the title amount of time.

answers: Federal Republic of Germany [or Bundesrepublik Deutschland]
parts: What capital of Bavaria, located on the River Isar, is noted for its many breweries, such as the 800-year-old Augustiner Keller, as well as its yearly Oktoberfest beer festival?
Munich is located in the southeast portion of this country, whose other cities include Hamburg and Frankfurt. It is the most populous country located entirely in Europe.

Munich's Nymphenburg Park contains one of these buildings. Elsewhere in Bavaria, Ludwig II built the famous Neuschwanstein (noy-SHVAAN-shtine) one of these buildings atop a hill, which remains a popular tourist attraction.

answers: Dill Harris [or Charles Baker Harris; accept any underlined portion]
parts: Name this book set in Maycomb, Alabama in which Tom Robinson is falsely convicted of raping Mayella Ewell despite the defenses of the lawyer Atticus Finch.
This American author who died in 2016 wrote To Kill a Mockingbird.
Lee's friendship with Truman Capote inspired this character in To Kill a Mockingbird. This character visits Maycomb every summer from Meridian and quickly becomes friends with Scout and Jem.

answers: processors [accept central processing units or CPUs]
graphics cards [accept graphics processing units or GPUs]
parts: These components were the focus of the race to 5 gigahertz, and can have one or multiple cores. Manufacturers of these components include Intel.
Primary manufacturers of these components include NVidia and AMD, and later iterations of these components have included hardware-accelerated ray tracing.
Computers use these devices to display things to users. In laptop computers, these screens are typically attached to the rest of the computer, while desktop computers often have separate versions.
Name this city in modern-day Italy, named for the brother of Remus. It eventually became the center of an empire whose gods included Jupiter, Mars, and Pluto.
Romulus and Remus were legendarily raised by one of these creatures, who were honored in the festival of Lupercalia.
After Romulus and Remus were abandoned on the banks of this river, its god saved them. This third-longest river in Italy flows through Rome.

answers: hats [accept specific types of hats like skullcaps]
parts: Name this position held by the spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism, currently occupied in exile in Dharamsala, India due to oppression by the Chinese government.
Tibetan Buddhists often worship by repeatedly chanting these sacred phrases, which include "om mani padme hum".
Tibetan Buddhists are split into schools named after "Red" and "Yellow" types of these garments. Muslims often wear one of these garments called a taqiyah during prayer.

answers: clinical depression [or major depressive disorder or MDD]
parts: Name this neurotransmitter often associated with pleasure and emotional highs. Anticipation of rewards increases the amount of this chemical in the brain.
This other neurotransmitter is believed to play major roles in mood and appetite, among other things. Its reuptake is inhibited by SSRIs.

SSRIs are often prescribed to treat this mental health condition which may be caused by a lack of serotonin. It can cause low self-esteem, a prolonged lack of happiness, or a loss of interest in previously enjoyable activities.

This man depicted himself with the title features in his Self-Portrait with Seven Fingers. He depicted a burning synagogue in his depiction of the Crucifixion, and his most famous work, I and the Village, was inspired by a village in Belarus.

This man depicted himself thrice in his Triple Self-Portrait. He also painted for the Saturday Evening Post, and depicted Ruby Bridges walking to school escorted by National Guardsmen in The Problem We All Live With.

Rockwell also created a series of paintings depicting this many freedoms. In another unusual self-portrait, Belgian surrealist René Magritte painted himself with this many arms, two more than the usual number.

Identify this number equal to the value of an extremely large exponentiation tower, which was popularized in a 1977 column by Martin Gardner, at which point it was the largest number ever used in a serious mathematical proof.

Graham's number is the upper bound to a problem from Ramsey theory, a subfield of graph theory which involves doing this process to graphs in certain ways. A famous computer-assisted proof by Haken and Appel showed that any map can have this process done to it with only four different labels.

Specifically, the problem asked for the smallest dimension n in which a complete graph on the vertices of an n-dimensional hypercube, if each edge were colored red and blue, must contain a mono-colored one of these shapes. These shapes have four equal sides and four right angles.

answers: 737 MAX airplanes [prompt on airplanes or passenger airplanes or 737 airplanes; accept but DO NOT OTHERWISE REVEAL answers like Boeing 737 MAX]
parts: Name these things which were withdrawn from service worldwide in March 2019 following two deadly accidents in 6 months caused by a faulty MCAS system which the manufacturer of these things failed to mention in their manuals.
This American aircraft manufacturer founded in Seattle produces the 737 MAX. Their primary competitor is Airbus, and their other planes include the double-decker 747.

A recent Boeing 737 crash that was not caused by manufacturing faults, meanwhile, occurred in January 2020 when Ukraine International Airlines flight 752 was shot down shortly after departing from Tehran, the capital of this country, by its military.
Ocean trenches are formed by this geological process, in which one tectonic plate slides under another at a convergent plate boundary.

The regions near subduction zones often contain large numbers of this type of mountain, examples of which include Mount St. Helens in Washington and Kilauea in Hawaii. These mountains typically eject large amounts of magma when they erupt.

These other undersea formations are caused by volcanic activity, usually at divergent plate boundaries. They may form “black smokers” or “white smokers”, and release warm, nutrient-rich water through the seabed, creating habitats for animals like the giant tube worm.
Name this force whose magnitude is equal to the product of the masses of two objects, times a namesake constant, divided by the square of the distance between them.
A common system involving Newton's laws of gravitation is a problem involving this many bodies orbiting each other. Newton also formulated this many laws of motion.
Lagrange found special cases of the three-body problem in which the bodies could exist in stable or unstable versions of this state. When the net force on an object is zero, it's in this state.

answers: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland [accept the UK or Great Britain; do NOT accept or prompt on "England"]
coal mining [accept word forms; prompt on mining by asking “for what resource?”]
parts: Name this first female European Prime Minister who was almost killed in an IRA bombing in Brighton.
Thatcher was the prime minister of this country, whose regions include Wales and Scotland and which has also been led recently by David Cameron.

Thatcher successfully ended a nationwide strike of people in this profession led by Arthur Scargill. This profession was concentrated in northern England and the Welsh mountains, and is also common in the U.S. in states like West Virginia.

answers: Avatar: The Last Airbender [or ATLA; prompt on Avatar alone]
parts: Name this 2017 movie adaptation of a manga and anime series about Light Turner finding a book with the power to kill.

The Death Note adaptation was headed by this streaming service after they bought the rights to the movie from Warner Bros. This streaming service's first original TV series, House of Cards, achieved widespread popularity.
In summer 2020, Netflix brought this animated series to its online streaming services. This series depicts Aang (rhymes with “bang”), who has the power to perform four different kinds of magic.

answers: Alexander the Great [or Alexander III of Macedon, or Alexandros ho Megas, or Alexandros III ho Makedon; prompt on Alexander or Alexandros]
Philip II of Macedon [or Philippos II ho Makedon; prompt on Philip]
the First Persian Empire [or the Achaemenid Empire, or Xšāça]
parts: Name this king of Macedon who built an empire spanning from Greece to India. He named many cities after himself, including one in Egypt home to a famous lighthouse.
This man was Alexander the Great's father. He was assassinated by one of his bodyguards and led the League of Corinth.
In the Battles of Issus and Gaugamela, Alexander defeated Darius III, the ruler of this large empire centered on modern-day Iran.
Name this collection in which pilgrims tell stories on a pilgrimage to the tomb of Thomas Becket.
This British author wrote The Canterbury Tales and was a contemporary of Giovanni Bocaccio.
This character in The Canterbury Tales tells a tale about Arcite and Palamon, who both fall in love with Emily upon seeing her. This character's tale follows the work's general prologue.
